column5:
Struggling with trust issues and opening up sucks. Common, but sucks. 

Do you have a problem with your therapist, or do you have a problem with the potential diagnosis theyâ€™ve suggested? Do you separate those two things in your mind? I ask because I think the distinction is important and lends itself to different ideas of how to move forward.

If youâ€™ve talked about the diagnosis â€œto deathâ€, can that just stop? If this is the only problem youâ€™re having, you can simply ask them to stop suggesting this right now. Maybe itâ€™s not true, or maybe youâ€™re not ready to hear it. Either way, can it be tabled for a later date? The diagnosis isnâ€™t as important as working through the symptoms youâ€™re having and having the support to manage those. 

I hear you. Although my diagnosis was thrown out there way faster than 9 months, when it got laid out there in black and white it threw everything for a loop. I bucked back (still do sometimes), tell them how it canâ€™t be true, etc. The only problem is, it is actually true. I just wasnâ€™t (am not) really ready to accept it. We didnâ€™t talk about it for a long time afterwards based on my reaction. Then we slowly brought small pieces of the diagnostic criteria into the room with us in conversation. Although it is really hard to hear, although I donâ€™t want it to be true, I canâ€™t really deny the black/white criteria outlined that I actually fit in to. So now itâ€™s less about â€œdo I have these diagnosesâ€ and more about â€œcrap, what does that even really mean for me, how I get help, how I accept myselfâ€. It also helped/hurt to have another professional with no ties to my T actually come up with the same diagnosis. Iâ€™m not saying you do/donâ€™t have the diagnosis your T is suggesting, Iâ€™m just suggesting some of this is a process and YOU get to decide how much you want to explore that label. If you donâ€™t want to discuss it, does it mean your therapy is suddenly over and they wonâ€™t help you any more? Probably not.

I also did everything I could to try and â€œprove them wrongâ€. Tried to muster every bit of energy to show up to session â€œnormalâ€, not talk about the â€œrealâ€ stuff because I didnâ€™t want to give them more insight that would only confirm what they were saying. Problem was, I left those sessions frustrated. Could no longer see the point in paying someone to have these pretend sessions. What was the point in having fake sessions every week, it certainly wasnâ€™t helping me move forward at all. So I decided to show up as me, screw what that meant about a diagnosis. 

Just be you. Whatever that means.

Okay, thanks! Pretty similar then. My T keeps saying they can tell Iâ€™m anxious, feeling unsafe, etc., but although I too can see/feel my body doing all this weird stuff, I donâ€™t actually THINK Iâ€™m anxious or unsafe, etc. Canâ€™t connect the two really at all. So it all just feels like this internal spasming monster I want to rip out of me because I canâ€™t wrap my brain around why itâ€™s there in the first place.

Part of that may be Iâ€™m not sure I ever learned how to identify how I feel? Spent all these years stoic, forcing no emotion at all, etc. Failing to pay attention to my body, completely disconnected from it while it went through all that. Now for some damn reason I guess my brain is starting to pay attention?

Similarly, I hadnâ€™t ever spoken my truth to anyone over the previous decades. Instead I grew this life-thing (mortgage, career, social life, etc). After some seemingly insignificant triggers, the last couple of years everything started to unravel, and it feels like Iâ€™m constantly on the edge of complete lack of any real existence. Thread by thread my life is falling apart around me, but I canâ€™t do shit to stop it. (I mean, I guess I could, my brain says I should be able to, but I just canâ€™t function.) Days of staying in bed because everything is too much. 5 hours to send a three sentence e-mail, etc. This is just my life now and that in itself I guess feels a little scary?

Iâ€™m sorry youâ€™re going through this. I donâ€™t know how this all ends for any of us, but there are people on this sub who swear it gets better so Iâ€™m trying to take in their confidence!

Hey. I think the other posters have given some good insight into where this may be coming from, what theyâ€™ve done. Just wanted to shout out and ask a question maybe?

40â€™s here too, and had been relatively okay most of my life. Now I feel like my body is afraid all the time, but cognitively Iâ€™m not actually afraid of anything I donâ€™t think? Wondering if thatâ€™s your experience too? Or do you like know youâ€™re unsafe? Can you identify what youâ€™re afraid of? 

Just wondering because this bodily reaction of constant shaking/spasms, etc. is excruciating, and is most certainly impacting my ability to function (do simple tasks, work, leave the house, think, interact with others, etc). But, at the same time cognitively I canâ€™t connect to any real thoughts of fear, safety, etc. I donâ€™t THINK Iâ€™m unsafe or afraid of anything, but my body is screaming differently. The only thing I can really identify as fear is maybe that this wonâ€™t ever go away? Ha.

I definitely didnâ€™t intend to say you were misunderstanding anything! My apologies! We all read everything a bit differently, but trying to match it up to our own experiences is where things gets messy. We understand or use concepts in a way that make sense to us or help us. I really was just curious about how much choice you believe we have in our responses. 

A lot work on battling my freeze response comes around anger (or at least thatâ€™s what my T is trying to help me balance at the moment). Accepting that anger is actually a valid emotion, one I can allow myself to feel. How to not get wrapped up in the anger in a way where I lash out at myself primarily. Because itâ€™s never been okay to send anger outward. But, itâ€™s also okay to be angry with others and to express the anger...Iâ€™m no where near being close to being able to do that safely. Iâ€™ll either end up really hurting myself in the process or doing things to others (not physically) that will be so hurtful and canâ€™t be taken back. 

I am no where with my freeze response around anything that connects with the trauma. And am quite frozen in other areas of my life where this response has just seeped over. Iâ€™m sorting through areas where I may be able to assert myself more freely and not get tons of unhealthy responses from others.

I believe this too! For other people though. Itâ€™s weird how much I can separate my beliefs and hopes for others from what I believe or hope for myself. If someone can outline what â€œthe right opportunityâ€ looks like, Iâ€™d be forever grateful. ğŸ˜‰

You donâ€™t sound dramatic, overreacting, or overly emotional. You sound like someone who is in a lot of pain. I donâ€™t hear it as complaining at all, I hear it as expression of reality. Your reality. And you may be surprised by how much I hear it as my reality too. I donâ€™t know how much time you spend ruminating, spinning all of this over and over again in your head, but based on what youâ€™ve said, maybe I do. Maybe I know exactly how you feel, exactly what it feels like to not be able to let thoughts go, exactly what it feels like to be in this type of pain. I donâ€™t know for sure. But...Iâ€™m in this sub because all of these things manifest in really painful ways in my life as well. Being numb for decades, finally cognitively understanding the scary feelings of dissociation but still being unable to stop them. Yep. There is a lot of pain here. There arenâ€™t good words to describe it. Have yet to find a magic bullet to cease the obsessive thought spiraling. Express yourself. Know no one here receives it as dramatic or complaining, we feel your pain even if we all feel it a bit differently. No huge solace in that, but youâ€™re not alone. And showing up to your therapy appointment, if anything, is another piece of the puzzle to remember you arenâ€™t alone in this. Wish you the best.

So much.

When my T first said theyâ€™d diagnosed me with PTSD and believed it was complex PTSD, I responded by saying it was a death sentence. No out, might as well off myself. 

I held on to to this complete denial and instead chose to go with believing my T was just overreacting and not skilled enough to really know. When my psychiatrist straight up said â€œyou have complex PTSDâ€, I walked out of the appointment empty.

What does this all mean? It feels like a life/death sentence. People can say as much as they want â€œit gets betterâ€, but does it? I can say the same mantra to anyone else, it will get better, but I donâ€™t believe it for myself. Why is everyone so hesitant to to say â€œyouâ€™ll have to deal with this your whole life. Youâ€™ll lose days/months/years of your life because you have CPTSDâ€? 

It never goes away, does it? Someone tell me it goes away. Because this is a life/death sentence Iâ€™m not sure is worth trying to fight.

I donâ€™t see it that way, one being â€œbetterâ€ than the other. Although there is some research out there that talks about outcomes for people a little differently depending on their FFF response. 

I guess Iâ€™d like to know, do you think we get to choose our response? That we have control over how our mind/body initially respond? I donâ€™t know that I see it that way. I sort of see our response as something primal, and looks different for us as individuals based on who we are, what we experienced, and all our other internal and external circumstances. 

Do I sort of wish i had a flight/fight response? Maybe. Because I have deep loathing and pathetic feelings around being a freezer. That being said, I also think all of our FFF responses manifest a bit differently. Seeing some peopleâ€™s â€œfightâ€ response can be damn scary, but otherâ€™s fight response manifests differently. 

I donâ€™t know that trying to swing your freeze/fawn response over to a fight/flight response is a required part of the process, and I wonder if thinking about it that way is actually harmful? My goal would be to move out of my freeze response to a response thatâ€™s balanced. I donâ€™t necessarily want a biological response to fight everything/everyone or to flee. Where is the middle ground? Maybe where I no longer freeze, but am able to find my voice and body actually expressing what I need, taking action to protect myself, but doing so in a way that is safe for me and for others. 

If my â€œfightâ€ response comes out, and I am looking for it, Iâ€™m looking for it in a way that allows me to accept itâ€™s okay for me to be angry, to fight back in a way that feels authentic to me, but not beating (physically or figuratively) everything/everyone around me. If my â€œflightâ€ response comes out, and Iâ€™m looking for it, I want it to manifest in a way that I leave people/situations that donâ€™t serve me, but not to run from everything. 

I donâ€™t even know what Iâ€™m saying. Sorry. What I will say is there is some research suggesting that treating freeze/fawn responses is more difficult than treating fight/flight. But, Iâ€™d guess you can find some research that would suggest opposition to that as well. No matter what, Iâ€™m trying to find that balance, not having any of these biological responses anymore. Finding a place where my body/mind are regulated enough to stay somewhere in the middle. Part of my own â€œhealingâ€ process is to find small ways I can move forward, make decisions, express myself, touch on the anger, understand my needs to push back, etc...but doing so slowly. To pull myself out of the â€œfreezeâ€ response, but not throw myself onto the opposite side of the spectrum.

Donâ€™t quit.

Iâ€™m guessing the thoughts youâ€™ve expressed here are things most of us have felt. What youâ€™ve described doesnâ€™t sound like a bad therapeutic relationship, it sounds like therapy. And itâ€™s hard. People really underestimate how difficult it is. To face these feelings, to want to quit, to think of every reason in the book to quit every week.

Iâ€™m a little callous about therapy in general, so take this as my maladaptive response to how I handle what youâ€™ve expressed, but it is what gets me to show up every week. Because somewhere in me I know Iâ€™m no longer at a place in my life that I can exist without it.

Iâ€™m acutely aware my T doesnâ€™t â€œcareâ€ about me. Not in the sense of the type of caring we actually NEED in real life. Their â€œcareâ€ is based primarily in collecting an income that allows them to live. However, your therapist cares about you in a bit of a unique way, regardless of the monetary attachment, because they could stop seeing you whenever they want. Refer you out. Tell you not to come back and fill your slot with someone else to make money off of them. So there is something about YOU. They are interested in you, interested in helping you, want to see you succeed, think they can help you, care about you in a way that aligns with therapy â€œcaringâ€, or they would dismiss you. Is there a chance they â€œcareâ€ about you much more deeply than that? Absolutely, and I believe some people take solace in that. I just donâ€™t. I wonâ€™t be living in a fantasy world. For me, my therapist cares only to the extent they need to to help me. And that is what Iâ€™m paying them for. 

And regardless of whether or not you have to pay for it at this time, you deserve to have the experience where someone listens to you, is curious about your thoughts, validates your experience, etc. Is it the same experience of having some unpaid person doing that in real life? Of course not, but it is still giving you something to know what that feels like. Itâ€™s a step towards something, not the end. 

As far as expressing your need for a hug...I think you could say that. In a way that allows you to be honest, but also protects you from the potential feeling of rejection when/if your therapist says â€œwell, I canâ€™t be the person to do thatâ€. Saying â€œI just need a hug or someone to hold meâ€ is different than saying â€œI need YOU to hug me or hold meâ€. To be fair, if my therapist attempted to touch me in anyway Iâ€™d freak the hell out, but the underlying truth is I need SOMEONE to just hold me. Are there ways your therapist can alter the ways they respond to you when you need a hug even if they may not be the person to do it? Probably. But, you wonâ€™t know if you donâ€™t say it. On the other extreme side of this, my therapist has ask me the same question yours asked you. I told them I needed them to shoot me. Asked them if they would. Of course, uh, no, they wonâ€™t. But just having those conversations is a break in vulnerability. A transition from â€œIâ€™m not going to tell you what I needâ€ into â€œI can express my needsâ€. That alone is a step forward, a new place to start from.

Donâ€™t quit. Show up. Iâ€™m aware of how damn difficult it is. And, frankly, most of the time I still donâ€™t know why I keep showing up. But, what I do know is making that commitment, continuing to JUST show up, is something. Even if thatâ€™s all you can really handle that week. Show up.
My life in a nutshell.

I hate this too. Like the word victim is dirty and disrespectful. Truth, weâ€™re likely all victims of something. 

The thing that irritates me the most is the side-by-side comparisons of â€œvictim mentalityâ€ to â€œsurvivor mentalityâ€ (or something comparable). I desperately wish people would see all those things listed under â€œvictim mentalityâ€ are actually people who have a helpless/hopeless mentality. And, sure as shit, victims often justifiably have this mentality. But itâ€™s not because their a victim, victims all present differently, itâ€™s because they in fact feel hopeless. 

And comparing that mentality, telling me I shouldnâ€™t have it, that I should wake up with a survivor mentality every day is just infuriating. I wake up as a victim and a survivor every damn day. And some days I feel hopeless and others I feel like I can handle anything thrown at me. Telling me which is â€œrightâ€ and which is â€œwrongâ€ only perpetuates everything about my existence apparently being wrong for this world. Thanks for the reminder asshats.

Chicken In A Biscuit crackers. Pringles. Fig Newtons. Budweiser. 

Go Figure. At least itâ€™s nothing that sustains life ya know?

Thank you for the understanding. It is very isolating to â€œknowâ€ things so deeply, but have them responded to with blatant positivity as if the thoughts should be easily changed in an instant. Unless experience tells you otherwise, I go with the evidence I collect and frankly the world has yet to confirm anything different.
Thank you for your kind reply.
Thanks for your reply. Sorry youâ€™ve been through so much.
Let me just say FUCK YOU before your post gets removed.
What you wrote is really beautiful and confirming. There is no right way for any of us to handle what weâ€™ve been given.

Iâ€™m not sure how to respond to this. But for some reason Iâ€™m sensing how brave it was for you to post this in a forum like this? I donâ€™t know. I feel pretty similarly, but donâ€™t feel like I would have been brave enough to say that here. Iâ€™ve never, not once, given voice to my PTSD diagnosis outside of a clinical setting. No one in my real world knows anything. I wonder a lot about what makes some people talk about it so openly and others not speak of it at all. And not just the diagnosis or the struggles associated with having PTSD, but also all the details behind what happened to them. So many posts and conversations of people openly sharing all of that, and I just wonâ€™t be that open. If anything, I end up landing on me being weak for being unable to be open about it vs. the other way around. But it fascinates me regardless. Sometimes I find myself judging them, others I find myself judging myself.

I wouldnâ€™t scream at you the first time. :) But I would push back at you for sure. Unfortunately I get the purpose of miracle questions, scaling questions, coping questions, blah blah blah because Iâ€™m professionally trained to use the same types of questions. I have to squash a lot of internal analyzing and judgement of my own T and the questions they use. I can be an ass of a client I guess. Use too many closed-ended questions and I start to count them in my head wondering when theyâ€™ll actually switch to something open-ended. Or Iâ€™ll start to just really respond with â€œyesâ€ or â€œnoâ€, etc. Give them only the specific answer to what they asked. Power play maybe? 

Itâ€™s a real problem in my therapeutic relationship actually, to let go of my professional self and just try to be there as a person. Iâ€™m trained to be the person that pushes back when I hear others ask poor questions to help them think through how to ask questions in a more purposeful way so they can get more information, so to say Iâ€™m somewhat of a challenging client is probably an underestimation of reality. Bless my T for putting up with all my shit. When I catch her putting on her T hat vs. just being a person and having a conversation, I start to feel like Iâ€™m in some sort of play and it feels icky. Luckily sheâ€™s pretty open to switching her questions when I buck back. Or will let me respond to things like scaling questions without a number...since you know, the number isnâ€™t really relevant at all itâ€™s just the beginning of the conversation. Itâ€™s so weird because Iâ€™ll pull all these types of questions out when Iâ€™m being the professional, but I hate to have them asked to me so obviously as a client. Puts me in a weird position. 

FYI...I would openly answer how I would know if therapy was working or not. :)

Thatâ€™s not a question that makes me what to scream. :)

Some examples:
If you could wake up to your perfect day tomorrow, what would it look like?
If you could wave a magic wand and make one big problem disappear, what would be gone?
Imagine you walk out this door and you instantly had the life you want to live, what does that life look like?

That could be sort of the lead up question or a follow-up question to a miracle question maybe, but the main point of the miracle question is to get a sense of what would be different if you did push that magic button. 

You could change the question your T asked to â€œThere is a magic button right in front of you, when you press it all of your problems will go away. What will be the first thing you notice is different when you push that button? How will your life look? Etc.â€

Then I guess I could see a follow-up question as to whether or not you would push the button if all of those things would actually come true.

I was about to say the exact same thing. Iâ€™ve said this to my T a hundred different ways, but they just wonâ€™t. I get their hesitation and all, but Iâ€™ve told them. And told them again. Itâ€™s crazy how much I can control and avoid because my T just wonâ€™t latch on and push. Stupid waste of time.
If I get asked one more â€œmiracleâ€ question, Iâ€™m going to scream.
Happiness, love, trust

Thank you for hitting on something, something that is actually quite difficult to navigate. The â€œaverageâ€ professional doesnâ€™t cut it for me. And I do struggle with trying to balance my own professional ego around it with trying to accept them for their professional expertise. I do think there is a bit of intimidation involved, an unknown of how to deal with â€œone of their ownâ€, that they are often unwilling to admit (or unable to self-reflect enough to recognize). 

I do have some level of respect for my current T who has somewhat openly said they were worried they didnâ€™t have the skills to help me, but they have tolerated me and I can see they are trying on some level. My options are limited so I have tried to sit back and give grace to their short-comings and take from their expertise what I can. Starting to wonder if Iâ€™m doing it at a cost to myself though and then where that leaves me. If I could do this on my own, I already would have. 

Thanks for the extra thoughts this AM.
Thank you!

Geesh, yes! The â€œyouâ€™re fineâ€ narrative that comes out of them. In one way I recognize it as them attempting to try and keep me positive. On the other hand itâ€™s a complete denial of my reality.  

I hear this most around my work because I, ya know, still have a job. So they constantly say â€œbut youâ€™re still working so you can do itâ€. Reality is Iâ€™m still employed, not really still working...and there is a huge difference. If I hadnâ€™t been in this career for two decades and built a reputation that allows me to now crumble behind the scenes nearly undetectable, Iâ€™d be unemployed. Itâ€™s like they are waiting for my drifting car to crash into the tree before they wake up and see my reality. Drifting is not driving, but apparently itâ€™s â€œenoughâ€ to deem you really not so bad. Sigh.

Ugh. Thank you for speaking directly to the internal dialogue that I am the piece of shit. I was able to replace it with â€œthey are shitâ€ for a minute and it was helpful. Maybe not completely fair, but helpful at the moment.
Thank you for your kindness, support, and insight. Glad youâ€™ve found some balance between struggle and life.

So much of what you wrote feels so real to me. Thank you for your insight and support, it really means something. If my brain were working really well right now, Iâ€™d express my gratitude more eloquently. But...thank you.

A lot of this for sure. They continuously tell me to keep doing what Iâ€™m doing. Guess theyâ€™re out of ideas. But the truth is what Iâ€™m doing obviously is not working. Even when I explain the reality of what my days look like I just donâ€™t think they can picture me that way so it must not be true? It is exhausting. 

And hell if it doesnâ€™t mirror every time a little girl tried to tell, a young woman nearly disappeared...and no one could see. Because that kid had it all, they couldnâ€™t be suffering. Sigh.

Itâ€™s all clearly irrelevant or at some point over all these decades someone would have noticed. Someone would have cared.

Yes! I get worried often about trying to draw the line, because who am I to draw it? But I desperately also want people to think about the damage done with letting society spiral into this idea that everyone has PTSD. While itâ€™s important to support anyone who is struggling, when we reinforce the idea that any struggle equals PTSD we are taking away the specific support needed for those who actually suffer from PTSD. 

In some ways it is necessary to practice some gatekeeping around PTSD. How many of us actually struggle to find the specific services and skills and support we need? Too many. Having everyone try to wiggle their way into what is already a limited supply of expertise takes away from our access.

Absolutely. It was so hard to swallow my own reality, hearing the diagnosis was actually painful. Iâ€™m still struggle to accept it as truth most of the time. So when I do, when I admit this part of me, and someone turns around and says they think they may have PTSD too because they feel really sad...I donâ€™t know what to do with that. I donâ€™t want them to be sad, I want to hear them and help, but I canâ€™t help but get a little destroyed by the insinuation they have any idea what itâ€™s like to actually have PTSD.

Thank you, that makes a lot of sense. I find the stigma around BPD so odd, getting how much it is often rooted in trauma as well, but also just because I donâ€™t relate much to how dropping a label on someone suddenly makes them â€œthisâ€ or â€œthatâ€ type of person. I guess there is still a lot of stigma around PTSD as well, but society in general seems to be opening up some to it. Perhaps theyâ€™ll get their heads out of their asses about BPD at some point as well.

I remember the first time my mental health â€œteamâ€ very pointedly said to me they knew I was dissociating and were sorting through derealisation vs. depersonalization and blah blah. I was staring back at them like wtf? Yeah, it didnâ€™t make sense until it just made sense. I later mentioned it to a friend and they looked at me like I had two heads and saw aliens or something. I havenâ€™t mentioned it again to anyone. :)
Yep.

Truth.

Confession: I grind the crap out of my teeth.

Of course you can add, thatâ€™s why weâ€™re here! You really speak to the activism thatâ€™s needed. For ourselves, for others. To pinpoint the real issues, reflecting on your own symptoms, looking at the realistic options-not the easiest, and going that direction. Taking the time to figure it out, to know, and not jumping off and following blindly into something that just doesnâ€™t make any true sense. Youâ€™re so right, raise hell. Just raise it in a logical direction. So glad you finally had someone listen to you and found something that has been so helpful. Iâ€™m on the hypothyroidism bus too, along with a couple other things. Balancing the mental health and medical health field is a true nightmare I understand. Medical professionals say...oh that must be because of your mental health. Mental health professionals say...oh that must be some physical health reason. Guess what jackhats, they arenâ€™t necessarily siloed issues and I need one of you to invest enough to help me get to the bottom of it!
Wow. Iâ€™m so glad you spoke to this. I maybe needed to hear it today. Thank you.

I hear every word of this. Truth there was a bit of snark behind my post (of course). Itâ€™s like standing on this tiny balance beam, trying to remain empathetic and understanding but at the same time balancing a level of frustration on the other side. 

Irony perhaps, but my history taught me any feelings of anger or frustration should just be beaten out of me until I complied and turned into the neutral and calm person I was supposed to be. So a bit of sarcasm and pointed words balanced just so became the only way to survive. Too angry, too disagreeable, too empathetic, too soft, too anything...just not an acceptable person to be.

I know. Itâ€™s a slippery slope of understanding and frustration. I find myself wanting to scream sometimes then having to step back. Because at the core of it all, I do understand. But honestly I sought out the sub after my diagnosis a little over a year ago and really did so to find some way to understand the depth and find some solace in not being alone. To be able to sort through the struggles, not to be focused on if some one does or doesnâ€™t have a diagnosis. Truth is, I donâ€™t care if you have the diagnosis, if you are struggling with something that aligns to PTSD, letâ€™s talk about it here. I donâ€™t want the damn diagnosis to start with, Iâ€™d erase it if I could. But scrolling through 3 posts of someone asking for a diagnosis to find the 1 post actually venting/seeking support/whatever sometimes frustrates me to the point I miss opportunities to connect with the underlying purpose of why a lot of us are here. But, I guess thatâ€™s a totally selfish perspective, and I do understand being at the point where youâ€™re just trying to find some explanation for what youâ€™re experiencing. Sigh. Rambling.

Love the addition. I think it really highlights the importance of treating and managing the symptoms vs. everything being about a diagnosis. (Iâ€™d guess you didnâ€™t totally mean it that way, so donâ€™t mean to take away from your overall gist, it just spoke to me that way.)

Can I ask a personal question, with the obvious disclaimer of feeling no pressure to respond, Iâ€™m just really curious because Iâ€™m not as honed in on it personally....

Do you find as many people seemingly curious or looking for a BPD or DD diagnosis as it seems like they seek a PTSD diagnosis? If so, how does that feel to you? If not, why do you think they donâ€™t? (Ugh, I hope that doesnâ€™t come off as a weird question or feel ugly to you. I just get my mind wrapped around some things and then like to hear other peopleâ€™s perspectives. My sincere apologies if that comes off weird.)

â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

For being late.
For not showing up to an appointment.
For answering this text really quickly.
For not telling you that.
For being so focused on what I thought I failed to listen to you.
For not asking the follow up questions I should have.
For not adjusting my approach to meet you where you are.

I donâ€™t need them to be perfect, but it would be nice for them to acknowledge their own faults instead of leaving it on me as if Iâ€™m the only one in the room who messes up.

Iâ€™m actually at peace with the outcome. There are just a couple things I wanted help sorting out beforehand. Iâ€™ll stay alive until those things are resolved. 

Itâ€™s interesting because therapy seems to only be supporting this decision, making it easier to accept. Seems a bit backwards, I know. But, youâ€™re right, talking about this piece may help alter how we work on the other things. Appreciate your response.

Right? I think thatâ€™s the point. Iâ€™m actually at peace with the outcome, so not sure it makes any difference to discuss it. It is really just a question because the T always starts by asking about the week, etc. and this is just a tangible piece of the week. Canâ€™t decide whether to skip over it or not.
I didnâ€™t, youâ€™re right, but itâ€™s totally fine. ;) Itâ€™s a natural response I completely understand. Appreciate your suggestions. Glad youâ€™ve found something that works for you!
Simply put. And fair. Thanks.

Sounds like you have a good T! I appreciate your clarity and thoughtfulness on this. In a lot of ways itâ€™s so weird to talk about so openly, but there is some relief of getting to the space where at least itâ€™s out there. Writing and talking about it helps sort through what can sometimes get fuzzy. Glad to hear youâ€™re not so far into your thoughts...it is definitely the time to talk about it with your therapist. Theyâ€™ve given you the open door, but I know how bizarre it can feel to walk through it.
Thanks for such a thoughtful reply. It does actually give me some things to think about!
What makes you lean that way? Like what are the benefits of talking about it?
